chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to install and run &gs; on computers running Windows or Linux. Note that there are two choices for installing in Windows. One is to install an all-in-one bundle of Python/Numpy/Pillow/GaussSum (the easier method), the other is to install the &gs; sources and the required libraries separately.

section.title: Installing an all-in-one bundle on Windows
section.para: Download the quite large all-in-one bundle from here. Extract the zip file into something like C:\Program Files\GaussSum2.3. To run, just doubleclick on GaussSum.exe. You may find it useful to create a shortcut on your desktop to GaussSum.exe (to do so, right-click on an empty part of the desktop, choose New -> Shortcut, browse to the folder where you installed &gs; and choose GaussSum.exe). If you want to set a startup folder, right-click on the icon, choose Properties -> Shortcut -> Start in:, and type the name of the startup folder.

sect2.title: Install &py;
sect2.para: &gs; requires &py;, which is a programming language commonly used for scripting.

Go to the Python install page. Download and run the Windows installer for a recent version of Python 3 (e.g. Python 3.3.2). Install it into something like C:\Python3.3. &gs; also works well with Python 3.1 and 3.2.

sect2.title: Install Numpy
sect2.para: &gs; requires Numpy, which is a Python extension that allows efficient matrix algebra.
Go to the Numpy download page. Download and run the Windows installer for your version of Python.

sect2.title: Install the Python Imaging Library (PIL)
sect2.para: In order to create .png images, &gs; requires the Python Imaging Library, which is a Python package that allows image manipulation.
Go to the PIL download page. Download the run the Windows installer for your version of Python.

sect2.xreflabel: Install the GaussSum Python scripts and &gp;
sect2.title: Install the &gs; Python scripts and &gp;
sect2.para: The scripts can be found here. Extract the zip file into something like C:\Program Files\GaussSum (note: &gp; is included in this zip file in the sub folder gnuplot400).

Create a shortcut on your desktop to GaussSum.py (to do this, right-click on an empty part of the desktop, choose New -> Shortcut, browse to the folder where you installed &gs; and choose GaussSum.py). To change the icon, right-click on the icon, choose Properties -> General -> Change Icon -> Browse. Find the folder where you installed &gs; and choose GaussSum.ico. In addition, change the program used to open &gs; by following these instructions: right-click on the icon, choose Properties -> General -> Opens with -> Change -> PythonW. If you want to set a startup folder, right-click on the icon, choose Properties -> Shortcut -> Start in:, and type the name of the startup folder.
If you have any questions or requests, or if you wish to be added to the mailing list for information on new versions and bug fixes, please send an email to gausssum-help@lists.sourceforge.net.

sect2.title: Start &gs;
sect2.para: Just double-click the shortcut to GaussSum.py to start &gs;.

sect2.title: Install &gp;
sect2.para: Check to see if you already have &gp;, by typing 'which gnuplot' in a shell window. If &gp; is installed, you need to make sure that it is version 4.0 or newer ('gnuplot --version').

If you need to install &gp;, rpms are available from rpmfind.net and gzipped tar files from SourceForge. If you are using Debian Linux, &gp; will be downloaded and installed if you issue the following command as root: 'apt-get install gnuplot'.

sect2.title: Install &py;
sect2.para: Check to see if you already have &py;, by typing 'which python' in a shell window.

If you have &py;, type 'python'. The version number should be displayed. If this is less than 3.1, the scripts may not work with your currently installed &py; version. (Press 'CTRL+D, ENTER' to exit.)

If you need to install Python, follow the appropriate instructions for your system at www.python.org. You should install the latest version of Python 3.3 (although Python 3.1 and 3.2 also work fine with &gs;). If you are using Debian Linux, &py; will be downloaded and installed if you issue the following command as root: 'apt-get install python3 python3-tk'.

sect2.title: Install Numpy
sect2.para: Numpy is an extension to Python that allows efficient matrix manipulation. You should try to find a binary package for your system rather than compiling it yourself (check your package management system). If you are using Debian Linux, Numpy will be downloaded and installed if you issue the following command as root: 'apt-get install python3-numpy'.

sect2.title: Install Pillow
sect2.para: The Python Imaging Library is a Python package that allows manipulation of images. &gs; requires PIL to handle PNG images. You can get PIL 1.1.7 from here under "Python Imaging Library 1.1.7 Source Kit (all platforms)". This should be untarred into a folder in the usual way, using 'tar zxvf Imaging-1.1.7.tar.gz'. Next, go into the folder created and (as root) install the package as follows: 'python setup.py install'.
If you are using Debian Linux, the Python Imaging Library will be downloaded and installed if you issue the following command as root: 'apt-get install python-imaging python-imaging-tk'.

sect2.title: Download &gs;
sect2.para: Download a gzipped tar of &gs; here. This should be untarred into a folder in the usual way, using 'tar zxvf GaussSum-&pointversion;.tar.gz'.
If you wish to be added to the mailing list for information on new versions and bug fixes, please send an email to gausssum-help@lists.sourceforge.net.

sect2.title: Start &gs;
sect2.para: To run &gs;, change directory to the &gs; directory and type 'python GaussSum.py'. You can also pass a filename as an argument: for example, 'python GaussSum.py myoutputfile.out'.
